abstract.p: Indoor air quality (IAQ) is an important factor, which can influence the health and comfort of passengers in subway stations. Various types of hazardous pollutants, such as particulate matters, remain accumulated in the subway space due to overcrowding and inadequate ventilation system. Subway stations are extremely crowded during rush hours and indoor air of the subway stations could be strongly affected, which in turn, affects passengers’ respiratory system. In this study, several key air pollutants data were collected every minute by the air sampler and tele-monitoring system (TMS) to effectively monitor and control IAQ in subway stations. The quality of the online measurement could decide the failure and success in environmental process assessment. Therefore, prompt detection of the occurrence of sensor faults and identification of those locations are of primary importance for efficient monitoring and control of IAQ. In this paper, Principal components analysis based approach is used to detect, identify and reconstruct the sensor faults in monitoring IAQ. Four types of sensor failures, namely, bias, drifting, complete failure and precision degradation are tested for monitoring IAQ. Several test results of a real subway TMS showed that the developed sensor validation technique can work well for the four kinds of sensor faults.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Subway stations have been considered as the most convenient way of commuter transportation in metropolitan areas. Large number of people, in metropolitan areas, commute regularly using underground metro systems in Korea. Although passengers are exposed to subway station for only a short time, the exposure to particulate matter air pollution can cause harm or deleterious effects on their health, such as mortality, respiratory symptoms and lung malfunction [1–7]. Indoor air quality (IAQ) in subway systems can be affected by many factors, such as the number of passengers, the outside conditions and the natural ventilation rate [8–10], etc. The management and monitoring of IAQ in subway stations has become an important issue of public interest.

Sensors are important components for monitoring IAQ in subway systems, and they provide the data needed for continuous online implementation. Sometimes, these sensors in subway stations suffer poor data quality and sensor reliability due to the hostile environment, in which the measurement equipment are installed for monitoring and may fail. The quality of the online measurement could decide the failure and success in process monitoring and assessment. Although most researchers and practitioners agree with this fact, surprisingly little attention has been given to the study of sensors in a realistic manner [11,12].

Sensors may exhibit partial failures such as bias, drifting, complete failure or precision degradation as displayed in Figure 1. These failures could reduce the accuracy and reliability of the measurement, which may result in an erroneous control action and false perception on the performance of the monitoring system. Faulty sensors that are either completely or partially failed (hard fault or soft fault) could provide incorrect information for monitoring and control. This can be detrimental to various data-driven decision schemes. Moreover, data may not be available due to sensor malfunction or communication problems within the data collection system. These problems could make it difficult to extract and interpret information from data. As a result, monitoring or control based on the incorrect measurements would become problematic. Fig. 1.
Four common types of sensor faults: (a) bias, (b) drifting, (c) complete failure and (d) precision degradation. The hollow circle represents normal sensor measurement and the filled dot represents faulty sensor measurement.

Principal components analysis (PCA) is a useful multivariate analysis technology, which can reduce the dimensionality of a data set. PCA has been widely used for data compression, image compression, data dimension reduction, feature extraction, sensor validation and information reconstruction [13–18]. In our previous study [19], PCA has been applied to evaluate the changes of IAQ due to the changes in seasonal or operating conditions in underground space or subway system. In this study, PCA-based fault detection, identification and reconstruction approach has been developed to study the performance of sensors in a real subway station.

sec.title: Data Set Description
sec.p:
Several key air pollutants data are collected every minute using tele-monitoring system (TMS; Figure 2). Four weeks of data used in this work was collected from Seoul Metro station, on line number 3, from January 4 to January 31, 2010. The measured variables were the concentrations of nitrogen monoxide (NO), nitrogen dioxide (NO2), nitrogen oxides (NOx), particulate matter with diameter <10 µm (PM10), particulate matter with diameter <2.5 µm (PM2.5), carbon monoxide (CO), carbon dioxide (CO2), temperature and humidity in the air of the platform area (Figure 3). Fig. 2.
TMS system used for data collection in a subway station. Fig. 3.

NO, NO2 and NOx concentrations were measured by the chemiluminescence of nitro-oxides materials; PM10 and PM2.5 concentrations were measured using beta-ray attenuation principle with the corresponding size distribution filters. CO and CO2 concentrations were measured using non-dispersive infrared radiation absorption of CO and CO2 molecules at the specific wavelengths. Table 1 provides the details of the detection limits and measurement accuracies of the equipment used in TMS system. Measurements were recorded every minute at each station (using TMS) and these were averaged hourly for further analysis. Table 1.

sec.title: Sensor Fault Identification
sec.p: When a faulty sensor is verified by the SPE plot in the fault detection step, the following step is used to determine the faulty sensor among all possible sensors. Given the right fault direction, the vector samples can be expressed as follows: (15)
where x* represents the part of the normal measurements, f is fault size, ξi is fault direction which is denoted with a unit vector.

To identify the true fault source of sensors, Dunia et al. [22] proposed a sensor validity index (SVI) method. The main idea of this identification approach is to reconstruct x* from x among all possible fault directions, ξi(i = 1,2,…,m). In the beginning one sensor was supposed to be faulty, the recovered measurement would be estimated from the remaining sensors based on the reconstruction methods which try to minimize the SPE. If the direction of the fault was chosen correctly, the obvious reduction in the value of reconstructed SPE(xj*) would be obtained. On the contrary, if the direction was not selected properly, the value of reconstructed SPE(xj*) would not change significantly. SVI, the index used for faulty sensor identification, would be determined by Equation (16) as follows [22]: (16)
where xj* is the vector of measurement x along the direction of the jth sensor fault after reconstruction.

The SVI plot was used to identify the possible sources of the faulty sensors. Generally speaking, if the value of SVIj was less than 0.5, ξj would be considered to be in the direction of sensor fault. Instead, if the value of SVIj was greater than 0.5, ξj would not be considered in the direction of sensor fault.

sec.title: Determining the Number of Principal Components
sec.p: In general, all of the score and loading vectors are not required to explain important data information. In practice, only a few PCs would be needed to process most of the variations in the data. When designing the PCA model, the number of PCs must be determined and this determination should consider both the reduction of dimensionality and the loss of data information. Several techniques exist in the literature [20,24,25] to estimate the number of PCs, including scree plotting, parallel analysis, cross-validation and the Akaike Information Criterion (AIC).

To get the best reconstruction performance of faulty sensor, Qin and Dunia [26] proposed the unreconstructed variance (URV) method to determine the number of PCs for best reconstruction. The URV is based on the estimation of a certain sensor by using the remaining measurements. There is always a portion of the measurement variation that cannot be reconstructed using the remaining sensors. This portion is the reconstruction error. sec.title: Dealing with Outliers and Missing Data
sec.p: Due to faults in sensors or unusual disturbances, outliers and missing data can be found by carefully checking the available data. Outliers and missing data can have an unwanted effect on model quality, especially in the data-driven model such as PCA model. To detect outliers, PCA method can be used directly to detect outliers by analysing T2 and SPE plots and searching for the data that lie outside their threshold values [27]. Besides, Fortuna et al. [28] applied Jolliffe’s three parameters method [29], named d2,d22,d32, in detection of outliers for a debutanizer column. The use of Jolliffe parameters with PCA gave consistent results when compared with results of 3σ edit rule and linear regression methods. Hence, the Jolliffe’s three parameters method is accepted as the standard procedure for detection of outliers. For the ith sample, the three parameters are calculated as follows: (21) (22) (23)

Dealing with missing data is another important step before applying PCA model to detect and diagnose sensor faults. There are a number of alternative ways of dealing with missing data [30–33]. The simplest approach is the listwise deletion method. This method has two main disadvantages: the first one is that this method may lose some useful information of system process, and the other disadvantage is that the method is time consuming and hard to implement if the data set is large. Substitution method can be regarded as a more advanced method when compared with the listwise deletion method. It replaces missing data points with reasonable approximations. sec.title: Integrated Scheme of Sensor Validation for Monitoring IAQ in a Subway Station
sec.p:
Figure 5 shows the integrated scheme of sensor validation for monitoring IAQ in a subway station. The implementation of the proposed method would consist of two parts, build a PCA model, and use this model to detect, identify and reconstruct the sensor faults. First, collect the measured data set and pre-process the original data by checking the outliers and missing data. The checked data would then be labelled as training data. Second, develop a PCA model using the training data for further analysis. Determining the optimal number of principal components would need to be involved in this step. In the other part of the scheme, that is, sensor validation, suppose sensor fault has been detected by comparing the value of SPE against its threshold, then the value of SVI would be used to identify the source of the sensor faults among all possible fault directions. Finally, the iterative reconstruction algorithm would be used to reconstruct the faulty sensor. Fig. 5.
Flow chart of sensor validation for monitoring indoor air quality in a subway station.

sec.title: Prediction of Outliers and Missing Data
sec.p: The hourly mean values for each variable from January 4 to January 31, 2010 with a total number of 672 observations were used in this study. The first 504 observations were used to develop a PCA model without sensor fault. The remaining 168 observations were used as a test data set in order to verify the proposed sensor validation method.

In this study, the Jolliffe’s three parameters method was used to find the outliers. Figure 6 clearly shows that sample number of 162 is detected as one outlier since the values of all the three parameters are extremely high compared to their threshold values. After deleting this abnormal point and filling with a reasonable value, a new training data would be available for rebuilding a PCA model. Fig. 6.
Outlier detection by Jolliffe’s three parameters method.

sec.title: Building PCA Model for Sensor Validation
sec.p:
Using the new training data, PCA model can be obtained for sensor validation. The first step in sensor validation scheme was to determine the number of PCs for best reconstruction. Figure 7 shows the variation of URV versus the number of PCs. When the number of PCs is three, the URV is at a minimum. The optimal number of PCs would be three in this case. On the other hand, three PCs corresponding to the three largest eigenvalues could explain 84.70% of the total variance of the system, as shown in Table 2. Therefore, the value with the number equal to three PCs was used for the PCA model in sensor validation. Fig. 7.

sec.title: Sensor Fault Validation
sec.p:
To verify the sensor validation scheme, four types of sensor faults, namely bias, drifting, complete failure and precision degradation, were introduced to one sensor as a single fault as listed in Table 3. The bias and complete failure were introduced to the sample 100 of PM10 sensor, individually. The drifting fault and precision degradation were introduced to the sample 80 of temperature sensor and the sample 100 of NOx sensor, respectively. Table 3.

sec.title: Sensor Bias
sec.p:
In the first test, a bias of 150 μg/m3 was introduced to the sample 100 of PM10 sensor. The value of SPE statistic was calculated using PCA model and compared to its threshold to detect the sensor fault in IAQ monitoring system. To identify the faulty sensor, the value of SVI of each sensor was calculated using the reconstruction based method. Figure 9(a) and (b) shows the sensor fault detection and identification results for the PM10 sensor, respectively. Fig. 9.
Fault detection, identification and reconstruction indices for bias fault of PM10 sensor: (a) fault detection, (b) fault identification and (c) fault reconstruction.

Before the artificial faulty sensor was introduced, the value of SPE was below the threshold, and the values of SVIs of all sensors were close to 1. After introduction of the bias fault, the value of SPE was found to exceed its threshold immediately. At the same time, the value of SVI for the PM10 sensor began to be close to 0. However, the SVIs of the other sensors were still close to 1 (not shown in Figure 9(b)). The SPE plot indicates that a fault has occurred among the sensors right at the sample 100, and the SVI plot shows that the fault has occurred on the PM10 sensor.
Figure 9(c) shows the values of measured and reconstructed measurements of the PM10 sensor under the bias fault. The reconstructed measurements were highly consistent with the normal measurements.

sec.title: Drifting Fault
sec.p: In the second test, a shifting fault, 0.5°C/h was introduced to the sample 80 of the temperature sensor. The value of SPE statistic was calculated using PCA model and compared with its threshold to detect the sensor fault in IAQ monitoring system. To identify the faulty sensor, the value of SVI of each sensor was calculated using the reconstruction based method.

Figure 10(a) and (b) shows the sensor fault detection and identification results for the temperature sensor, respectively. Before the fault was introduced, the value of SPE was below the threshold, and the values of SVIs of all sensors were close to 1. At the sample 90, the value of SPE began to exceed its threshold. At the same time, the SVI of the temperature sensor began to approach 0, whereas the SVIs of the other sensors remained close to 1 (not shown in Figure 10(b)). The time lag was shown to be dependent on the drifting magnitude of the sensor fault. Fig. 10.
Fault detection, identification and reconstruction indices for shifting fault of temperature sensor: (a) fault detection, (b) fault identification and (c) fault reconstruction.

Figure 10(c) shows the values of the measured and reconstructed measurements of the PM10 sensor under the bias fault. The reconstructed measurements were highly consistent with the normal measurements.

sec.title: Complete Failure
sec.p: In the third test, a complete failure fault, 200 μg/m3 was introduced to the sample 100 of the PM10 sensor. The value of SPE statistic was calculated using PCA model and compared with its threshold to detect the sensor fault in IAQ monitoring system. To identify the faulty sensor, the value of SVI of each sensor was calculated using the reconstruction based method.

Figure 11(a) and (b) shows the sensor fault detection and identification results for the PM10 sensor, respectively. Before the fault was introduced, the value of SPE was found below its threshold, and the values of SVIs of all sensors were close to 1. After introduction of the complete failure fault, the value of SPE was found to move to exceed its threshold immediately. At the same time, the value of SVI for the PM10 sensor began to be close to 0. However, the SVIs of the other sensors were still close to 1 (not shown in Figure 11(b)). The SPE plot indicates that a fault has occurred among the sensors right at the sample 100, and the SVI plot shows that the fault occurred on the PM10 sensor. Fig. 11.
Fault detection, identification and reconstruction indices for complete failure fault of PM10 sensor: (a) fault detection, (b) fault identification and (c) fault reconstruction.

Figure 11(c) shows the values of measured and reconstructed measurements of the PM10 sensor under the complete failure fault. The reconstructed measurements were highly consistent with the normal measurements.

sec.title: Precision Degradation
sec.p: In the final test, precision degradation fault, σ = 0.5 was added to the sample 100 of the NOx sensor. Similarly, the value of SPE statistic was calculated using PCA model and compared with its threshold to detect the sensor fault in IAQ monitoring system. To identify the faulty sensor, the value of SVI of each sensor was calculated using the reconstruction based method.

Figure 12(a) and (b) shows the sensor fault detection and identification results for the NOx sensor, respectively. Before the fault was added, the value of SPE at each sampling point was found to be within the threshold, and the values of SVIs of all sensors were found close to 1. Immediately after the fault was added, the value of SPE was fluctuated with a magnitude significantly greater than the threshold. At this time, the value of SVI of the NOx sensor began to fluctuate between 0 and 1, and the values of SVIs of the other sensors remained close to 1 (not shown in Figure 12(b)). This feature indicates obviously that the fault has appeared and occurred on the NOx sensor. Fig. 12.
Fault detection, identification and reconstruction indices for precision degradation fault of NOx sensor: (a) fault detection, (b) fault identification and (c) fault reconstruction.

Figure 12(c) shows the values of measured and reconstructed measurements of the NOx sensor under the precision degradation. The reconstructed measurements were highly consistent with the normal measurements.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The precision and the reliability of sensors are very important for monitoring, diagnosis and control of IAQ. To deal with the faulty sensors of the IAQ, a sensor validation scheme based on the PCA method has been developed which is presented with sensor fault detection, identification and reconstruction strategy. A large amount of data was collected under the normal conditions from Seoul subway station to train a PCA model. SPE statistic based on the PCA model was used to detect sensor faults occurring in the data of IAQ by comparing SPE value to its threshold. After a fault was detected, the SVI plot would be used to identify which sensor was faulty. Finally, the misleading measurement of faulty sensor was corrected based on reconstruction method. The validation and test results showed that the proposed method can be used to detect, identify and reconstruct the faulty sensors using the IAQ data obtained from subway station successfully. Thus, the developed PCA-based sensor validation method is the promising approach and can effectively monitor and improve the IAQ data obtained from subway systems.
